lg.l: Admire not Sir That I so long unseen
Have but in Secret thy Attendant been
That tortur'd Long I never dar'd till now
My hate of thee before the World avow
Still had I hid my fury in my breast
Would my relentless Snakes but let me rest
For long I·ve Learned my Lot ordaind by fate
To Raise those names most high whom most I hate
But oh it would not be! the Eating flame
Would out tho well I knew it seal'd thy fame
You may rejoyce your glory is secure
And it must now with time it self endure
Great Homer Maro Milton had from me
No greater favours than I·ve shown to thee
No greater Rage against them I display'd
Nor greater folly in that Rage betray·d
Nor thou tho dire I seem to weaker EyesThe glory Fond man the Glory of my hate despise
Not all the Crouds of Youths brought up by you
In every Godlike Art & Virtue too
By thee with Evry Nobler Science Grac'd
Distinguish'd for their Elegance of Tast
Not all the crouds that round thy pulpit throng
Rapt with the force of thy persuasive tongue
Not all the wretched by thy bounty Easd
Nor modest merit by thy friendship rais·d
Not all you eer can do or preach or write
Exalts your Glory equal to my spite
The Orator·s harangue the Poets Lays
Tho tuning all their notes to Virtues praise
The breathing marble and th'expressive Coin
Tho History with them her forces joyn
All these united cant true worth declare
Since oft th effects of flattery or Fear
True worth is best distinguish'd by my hate
That cannot be suspected of DeceitZ690421A
